articles.headline: Rajat Gupta Convicted of Insider Trading
articles.snippet: Rajat K. Gupta, the retired head of the consulting firm McKinsey & Company and a former Goldman Sachs board member, is the most prominent executive convicted in the government’s sweeping investigation into insider trading on Wall Street.
articles.abstract: Rajat K. Gupta, the retired head of the consulting firm McKinsey & Company and a former Goldman Sachs board member, is the most prominent executive convicted in the government’s sweeping investigation into insider trading on Wall Street.
articles.lead_paragraph: Rajat K. Gupta, the retired head of the consulting firm McKinsey & Company and a former Goldman Sachs board member, was found guilty on Friday of conspiracy and securities fraud for leaking boardroom secrets to a billionaire hedge fund manager.
articles.byline: By Peter Lattman and Azam Ahmed

articles.headline: Microsoft Is Expected to Introduce a Tablet
articles.snippet: The device, running a new version of the Windows operating system, would be the first computer of the company’s own design, and would be aimed squarely at Apple’s iPad.
articles.abstract: The device, running a new version of the Windows operating system, would be the first computer of the company’s own design, and would be aimed squarely at Apple’s iPad.
articles.lead_paragraph: For decades, Microsoft has made the software that runs a majority of the world’s personal computers, leaving a gang of outside hardware companies to design the machines. Apple, its rival, makes it all.

articles.headline: Russia Sending Missile Systems to Shield Syria
articles.snippet: Russia’s chief arms exporter said air and sea defenses could be used against any nation trying to halt Syria’s violence.
articles.abstract: Russia’s chief arms exporter said air and sea defenses could be used against any nation trying to halt Syria’s violence.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Russia’s chief arms exporter said Friday that his company was shipping advanced defensive missile systems to Syria that could be used to shoot down airplanes or sink ships if the United States or other nations try to intervene to halt the country’s spiral of violence.

articles.headline: Troubled Greek Economy Is Being Left to Fend for Itself
articles.snippet: International businesses and investors are retreating because of the prospect of a devalued currency and because consumption has plunged.
articles.abstract: International businesses and investors are retreating because of the prospect of a devalued currency and because consumption has plunged.
articles.lead_paragraph: ATHENS — No matter what happens in this weekend’s elections, Greece is rapidly becoming an isolated economy.

articles.headline: Target-Date Funds Not Equally Safe
articles.snippet: Not all target-date funds are the same. Some are heavily into stocks, while others are more conservative and mainly in bonds.
articles.abstract: Not all target-date funds are the same. Some are heavily into stocks, while others are more conservative and mainly in bonds.
articles.lead_paragraph: Let’s say you’re 63 years old and trying to figure out how to invest the money you’ve managed to put aside over the years.

articles.headline: Revamped Disney Park Tries Again
articles.snippet: The company unveiled $1.1 billion worth of improvements to its California Adventure park, which had been a disappointment since it opened 11 years ago.
articles.abstract: The company unveiled $1.1 billion worth of improvements to its California Adventure park, which had been a disappointment since it opened 11 years ago.
articles.lead_paragraph: ANAHEIM, Calif. — Thousands of people camped on the street overnight waiting to get in. Media coverage by more than 400 print, online and broadcast outlets. Dozens of costumed characters foxtrotting to “Ain’t We Got Fun.” Fireworks at 8 a.m.

articles.headline: Banks’ Fire Drill for Greece Election
articles.snippet: After being largely unprepared for the extreme stress of the 2008 crisis, big banks in the United States are determined to be ready this time.
articles.abstract: After being largely unprepared for the extreme stress of the 2008 crisis, big banks in the United States are determined to be ready this time.
articles.lead_paragraph: The banks are on high alert.

articles.headline: Victory Spurs Talk on Bharara’s Next Move
articles.snippet: Several top prosecutors for Preet Bharara, the United States attorney in Manhattan, have already left his office, and he appears to have switched his focus to cybercrime.
articles.abstract: Several top prosecutors for Preet Bharara, the United States attorney in Manhattan, have already left his office, and he appears to have switched his focus to cybercrime.
articles.lead_paragraph: With the conviction of Rajat K. Gupta, the United States attorney in Manhattan, Preet Bharara, has now secured the biggest scalp yet in the government’s broad campaign against insider trading on Wall Street.
articles.byline: By Azam Ahmed and Peter Lattman

articles.headline: At Romney’s Side, a Determined Running Mate
articles.snippet: Ann Romney has become much more visible on the stump in support of her husband, Mitt Romney, now that he has clinched the Republican presidential nomination.
articles.abstract: Ann Romney has become much more visible on the stump in support of her husband, Mitt Romney, now that he has clinched the Republican presidential nomination.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Years before Mitt Romney ever ran in his first political race, his wife, Ann, beat him to public office.

articles.headline: With Revolution’s Fate at Stake, Egypt Votes on President
articles.snippet: Turnout in the early hours was moderate in the race, which pits a former prime minister of Hosni Mubarak against a Muslim Brotherhood candidate.
articles.abstract: Turnout in the early hours was moderate in the race, which pits a former prime minister of Hosni Mubarak against a Muslim Brotherhood candidate.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Voters cast ballots on Saturday for the first competitively elected leader in Egypt’s history, even as a last-minute grab for power by its ruling generals raised questions about whether the election would be a milestone in the transition to democracy or a facade obscuring the re-emergence of the old order.
articles.byline: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK and KAREEM FAHIM

articles.headline: U.N. Suspends Syria Mission, Citing Increase in Violence
articles.snippet: The United Nations’ decision to pause observers’ work was the most severe blow yet to a wobbly peace plan world powers had seen as the best chance to solve Syria’s deadly conflict.
articles.abstract: The United Nations’ decision to pause observers’ work was the most severe blow yet to a wobbly peace plan world powers had seen as the best chance to solve Syria’s deadly conflict.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAIRO — The United Nations said Saturday that it was suspending its observer mission in Syria because of the escalating violence, the most severe blow yet to months of international efforts to negotiate a peace plan and prevent Syria’s descent into civil war.
articles.byline: By David D. Kirkpatrick and David E. Sanger

articles.headline: As Greeks Head to Polls Again, a Fear That No One Will Win
articles.snippet: Voters will cast ballots for the second time in two months, worried that any government they elect will fail to resolve the political and economic turmoil that threatens Greece’s future.
articles.abstract: Voters will cast ballots for the second time in two months, worried that any government they elect will fail to resolve the political and economic turmoil that threatens Greece’s future.
articles.lead_paragraph: ATHENS — Greeks head to the polls on Sunday for the second time in two months with a pervasive sense of dread that any government that comes to power will fail to resolve the political and economic turmoil that threatens the country’s future — and the financial stability of Europe itself.
articles.byline: By Rachel Donadio and Steven Erlanger

articles.headline: Meet Your Cousin, the First Lady: A Family Story, Long Hidden
articles.snippet: Research into Michelle Obama’s white relatives underscores the history of racial intermingling that binds countless American families decades after the Civil War.
articles.abstract: Research into Michelle Obama’s white relatives underscores the history of racial intermingling that binds countless American families decades after the Civil War.
articles.lead_paragraph: REX, Ga. — Joan Tribble held tightly to her cane as she ventured into the overgrown cemetery where her people were buried. There lay the pioneers who once populated north Georgia’s rugged frontier, where striving white men planted corn and cotton, fought for the Confederacy and owned slaves.

articles.headline: Honey, the Baby Is Coming; Quick, Call the Photographer
articles.snippet: Birth photography is a small but growing profession chronicling a rite of passage no less significant than a wedding, though trickier to capture on film.
articles.abstract: Birth photography is a small but growing profession chronicling a rite of passage no less significant than a wedding, though trickier to capture on film.
articles.lead_paragraph: Lynsey Stone does not set foot in the shower without placing her cellphone on a nearby ledge, lest she miss an urgent text from a woman in labor. She schedules vacations 10 months in advance to ensure they do not conflict with due dates, and on family outings she and her husband leave their Granbury, Tex., home in separate cars, in case she needs to race to the hospital.

articles.headline: Yes, Wall Street Can Reach Out
articles.snippet: A tiny firm is helping disabled veterans prepare for and find jobs in the financial world.
articles.abstract: A tiny firm is helping disabled veterans prepare for and find jobs in the financial world.
articles.lead_paragraph: WITH unemployment just above 8 percent, it’s clear that finding a job is tough for many Americans. But for war veterans, particularly disabled ones, it’s even tougher. Nearly one of every three young male veterans was out of work last year.

articles.headline: C.E.O. Pay Is Rising Despite the Din
articles.snippet: Although more companies have given their shareholders say-on-pay votes, median compensation still climbed by 5 percent last year among the United States’ 200 top-paid chief executives.
articles.abstract: Although more companies have given their shareholders say-on-pay votes, median compensation still climbed by 5 percent last year among the United States’ 200 top-paid chief executives.
articles.lead_paragraph: YOU call this a revolution?

articles.headline: Mapping, and Sharing, the Consumer Genome
articles.snippet: Few consumers may have heard of Acxiom, a database marketer. But it has amassed the world’s largest commercial data trove about them, analysts say.
articles.abstract: Few consumers may have heard of Acxiom, a database marketer. But it has amassed the world’s largest commercial data trove about them, analysts say.
articles.lead_paragraph: IT knows who you are. It knows where you live. It knows what you do.

articles.headline: Egypt’s Military Cements Its Powers as Voting Ends
articles.snippet: The Muslim Brotherhood projected its candidate as the winner of Egypt’s first competitive presidential election, hours after the ruling military council granted itself broad power over the future government.
articles.abstract: The Muslim Brotherhood projected its candidate as the winner of Egypt’s first competitive presidential election, hours after the ruling military council granted itself broad power over the future government.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAIRO — The Muslim Brotherhood early Monday projected its candidate, an Islamist, as the winner of Egypt’s first competitive presidential election, hours after the ruling military council issued an interim constitution granting itself broad power over the future government, all but eliminating the president’s authority in an apparent effort to guard against just such a victory.

articles.headline: Supporters of Bailout Claim Victory in Greek Election
articles.snippet: A party that had backed a bailout for Greece’s failed economy won a narrow victory in parliamentary elections seen as a last chance for the country to stay in the euro zone.
articles.abstract: A party that had backed a bailout for Greece’s failed economy won a narrow victory in parliamentary elections seen as a last chance for the country to stay in the euro zone.
articles.lead_paragraph: ATHENS — Greek voters on Sunday gave a narrow victory in parliamentary elections to a party that had supported a bailout for the country’s failed economy. The vote was widely seen as a last chance for Greece to remain in the euro zone, and the results had an early rallying effect on world markets.

articles.headline: Worried Banks Resist Fiscal Union
articles.snippet: European banks oppose a union, which is meant to encourage the free flow of money in Europe and halt the lending cycle between sick banks and debt-laden governments.
articles.abstract: European banks oppose a union, which is meant to encourage the free flow of money in Europe and halt the lending cycle between sick banks and debt-laden governments.
articles.lead_paragraph: The seemingly endless series of euro zone crises has European officials pushing for a banking union that would watch over and bind together the currency group’s faltering financial institutions.

articles.headline: Rodney King Dies at 47; Police Beating Victim Who Asked ‘Can We All Get Along?’
articles.snippet: Mr. King, whose 1991 videotaped beating by the Los Angeles police became a symbol of racial tensions and led to deadly race riots after the officers were acquitted, was found dead at 47.
articles.abstract: Mr. King, whose 1991 videotaped beating by the Los Angeles police became a symbol of racial tensions and led to deadly race riots after the officers were acquitted, was found dead at 47.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Rodney G. King, whose 1991 videotaped beating by the Los Angeles police became a symbol of the nation’s continuing racial tensions and subsequently led to a week of deadly race riots after the officers were acquitted, was found dead Sunday in a swimming pool at the home he shared with his fiancée in Rialto, Calif. He was 47.

articles.headline: Digital Media’s Ever-Swifter Incursion
articles.snippet: In just one week, developments solidified the future of a new kind of media, with The Huffington Post and Time Inc. both announcing new tablet offerings.
articles.abstract: In just one week, developments solidified the future of a new kind of media, with The Huffington Post and Time Inc. both announcing new tablet offerings.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last Wednesday night on the rooftop of the Gramercy Park Hotel, all the signs of the classic magazine launch party were on display: an open bar ringed by thirsty media reporters, groaning trays of shrimp, a D.J. playing music just soft enough that it didn’t drown out the chatter. The proud editor showed off his new product, the woman who is its namesake held court a few feet away, and the Pulitzer Prize-winning contributor was surrounded by a cluster of partygoers.

articles.headline: Apple and Google Go Head to Head Over Mobile Maps
articles.snippet: SAN FRANCISCO — Apple’s move into maps is hardly a surprise, but the question is if it can build a service that does as good a job, or a better one, than Google's does.
articles.abstract: SAN FRANCISCO — Apple’s move into maps is hardly a surprise, but the question is if it can build a service that does as good a job, or a better one, than Google's does.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Get ready for the mobile map wars.

articles.headline: In a World of Complications, Obama Faces a Re-election Test
articles.snippet: As President Obama left Sunday for a summit in Mexico, a daunting array of overseas issues underscored the challenges for an incumbent trying to manage global affairs while arguing a case for re-election.
articles.abstract: As President Obama left Sunday for a summit in Mexico, a daunting array of overseas issues underscored the challenges for an incumbent trying to manage global affairs while arguing a case for re-election.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For Barack Obama, a president who set out to restore good relations with the world in his first term, the world does not seem to be cooperating all that much with his bid to win a second.

articles.headline: Newspaper Work, With Warren Buffett as Boss
articles.snippet: Three years after saying he would not buy a newspaper at any price, Warren Buffett has moved aggressively into the business, buying 63 papers and taking a 3 percent stake in Lee Enterprises.
articles.abstract: Three years after saying he would not buy a newspaper at any price, Warren Buffett has moved aggressively into the business, buying 63 papers and taking a 3 percent stake in Lee Enterprises.
articles.lead_paragraph: BUFFALO — Over the years, newspaper owners have built monuments to themselves in the form of giant buildings, statues and plaques commemorating their roles in their communities and the country at large. At the headquarters of The Buffalo News here, a sand-colored office building across the river from a fragrant Cheerios factory, the only visible sign of the owner is a small photograph hanging in the office of the publisher, Stanford Lipsey, signed, “To the best in the business, Warren.”

articles.headline: Verifying Ages Online Is a Daunting Task, Even for Experts
articles.snippet: Recent sexual assaults on children by adults who pretended to be minors on Skout, a mobile social networking app, has highlighted the challenge of verifying ages online.
articles.abstract: Recent sexual assaults on children by adults who pretended to be minors on Skout, a mobile social networking app, has highlighted the challenge of verifying ages online.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Just how hard can it be to verify the age of a person online?

articles.headline: Greek Election Defuses One Crisis, but More Lurk
articles.snippet: Greece is expected to continue receiving the international aid it needs to stay afloat, but problems in Spain, Italy and the rest of Europe still need to be addressed.
articles.abstract: Greece is expected to continue receiving the international aid it needs to stay afloat, but problems in Spain, Italy and the rest of Europe still need to be addressed.
articles.lead_paragraph: Investors expressed relief over the projected victory of pro-bailout parties in the Greek elections on Sunday, but they quickly turned their attention to the structural problems in southern Europe that continue to threaten the global economy.
